User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:8.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/8.0
Build ID: 20111006182035

Steps to reproduce:

If you move mouse out of the tab bar where you’ve just closed some tabs to a viewport which is occupied by a plug-in, in my case it is Adobe Reader plug-in, a PDF file open within Firefox…


Actual results:

Than the rearrangement (widening) of the tabs to fill the whole tab bar (if they didn’t fill it after some of them were closed) stops when the mouse moves into the viewport (into the plug-in space) and continues only if you move it back e.g. over the address bar or bookmarks bar.


Expected results:

Firefox should start rearranging the tabs as soon as you move mouse out of the tab bar (or maybe the trigger is set somehow a bit else but it’s OK now) and nothing should stop it from finishing the rearrangement.

comments.text:
OK. I’ve found out that the steps to reproduce are maybe not exactly right. But I can reproduce it this way:

1. Let the initial arrangement be as in the Step 1 image. Some tabs open and among them there is a PDF file opened within Firefox.
2. Now let’s close the tabs to the right of the PDF tab, the cursor is still at the same place over the closing cross of the nearest tab to the right of the PDF tab. When closing the last tab to the right of the PDF tab, move cursor to the viewport where the PDF will appear right after the last tab was closed.
3. If you move the mouse to the viewport to quickly, the rearrangement of the tabs doesn’t start at all or it stops as you move the mouse over the viewport.

The resulting arrangement is seen in the Step 2 image. There you have a situation when the tabs should fill the whole tab bar but the rearrangement stopped when the mouse was moved over the viewport occupied by the plug-in.
